docs.lead_paragraph: As soon as they saw her patient's C.T. scan last June, radiologists paged Dr. Anne Dembitzer, an internist at the Veterans Affairs hospital in Palo Alto, Calif. ''They were really shocked,'' Dr. Dembitzer said. ''They said, 'You have to come down here and see what we found.' ''
docs.abstract: Researchers at Brigham and Women's Hospital, Boston, led by Dr Atul A Gawande report in New England Journal of Medicine that leaving objects in patient after surgery is 'uncommon but dangerous error' that can lead to severe infections, organ damage and even death; estimate sponges or instruments are left behind, despite precautions, at least 1,500 times a year in United States, where operations exceed 28 million a year; photos (M)
